statement.tex: %text Find the coordinates of the foot of the perpendicular and the perpendicular distance of the point $P(3.2.1)$ from the plane $2x-y+z+1=0$. Find also, the image of the point in the plane. %

step.context: %text If the foot of the perpendicular is a point $F$ whose coordinates are $(x_1,y_1,z_1)$, what is the relationship between $\ora{FP}$ and $\ora{N}$ the normal to the plane? %
step.reason: %text Since $\ora{FP}$ is a perpendicular to the plane and $\ora{N}$ is the normal to the plane, $\ora{FP}$ has to be parallel to $\ora{N}$. %

step.context: %text What equation(s) represent(s) $\ora{FP}\parallel\ora{N}$ for $F(x_1, y_1, z_1)$, $P(3,2,1)$ and $\ora{N}=\vector{2}{-1}{1}$? %
%text If point $F(x_1,y_1,z_1)$ lies on the plane $2x-y+z=-1$ and ${\small\dfrac{x_1-3}{2}=\dfrac{y_1-2}{-1}=\dfrac{z_1=1}{1}}$, what is $F(x_1,y_1,z_1)$? %
step.reason:
\begin{align} &\dfrac{x_1-3}{2}=\dfrac{y_1-2}{-1}=\dfrac{z_1=1}{1}=k \,\text{(say)}, \\ \implies& x_1=2k+3, y_1=-k+1, z_1=k+1 \end{align} \\
%text Since $F$ lies on the plane, it must also satisfy the equation of the plane $2x-y+z+1=0$. % \begin{align} &2x_1-y_1+z_1+1=0 \\ \implies &2(2k+3)-(-k+2)+(k+1)+1=0 \\ \implies &4k+6+k-2+k+2=0 \\ \implies &k=-1 \end{align} \\ %text Substituting $k$ back in the first equation we get $F(x_1,y_1,z_1)=(1,3,0)$ %

step.context: %text If $F(1,3,0)$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $P(3,2,1)$ and $R(x_2,y_2,z_2)$ is the reflection point of $P$, what is $D=|\ora{FP}|$ and what is $\ora{R}$? %
step.reason: %text The distance $D$, between $F\left(1,3,0\right)$ and $P\left(3,2,1\right)$ can be established using distance formula, % \begin{align} D &= \sqrt{(3-1)^2+(2-3)^2+((1-0)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{4+1+1}=\sqrt{6} \end{align} \\ %text Further, since $F$ is the midpoint between $P$ and reflection point $R(x_2,y_2,z_2)$, we can say, % \qquad\begin{align} \dfrac{x_2+3}{2}=1 &\implies x_2=-1 \\ \dfrac{y_2+2}{2}=3 &\implies y_2=4 \\ \dfrac{z_2+1}{2}=0 &\implies z_2=-1 \end{align} \\ \therefore R \left(-1,4,-1\right)
